misconceptions.name: Did not implement required grade input functionality
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a distance-between-points program instead of a grade calculator and never reads a numeric grade (0-100) from the user.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to compute the distance between two points rather than to read a numeric grade for a grade calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read a single numeric grade value (0-100) using a Scanner, then use it for further processing.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a grade
No variable representing a grade is read or stored
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about which problem is being solved or mixing up files from different assignments.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the coordinate prompts and four double inputs with a single prompt like "Enter grade:" and read one numeric value into a grade variable.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is focused on distance calculation; there is no grade-related input anywhere.

evidence.note: All inputs are coordinates; there is no input corresponding to a numeric grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for grade ranges A and B
misconceptions.description: The program does not contain any conditional statements to check whether a numeric grade falls into the A (90-100) or B (80-89) ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they only need to compute distance and not classify a grade into letter categories.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use if/else-if conditions to test whether the grade is between 90-100 (A) or 80-89 (B), inclusive, and branch accordingly.
symptoms: No if or else-if statements related to grade values
No variables or expressions comparing against 80 or 90
misconceptions.root_cause: Solving an entirely different problem than specified.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading a grade variable, add conditional checks like `if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... }` to handle A and B ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditionals at all; the behavior is purely arithmetic for distance.

evidence.snippet:
double distanceBetweenPoints = Math.sqrt(differenceX * differenceX + differenceY * differenceY);

System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distanceBetweenPoints);
evidence.note: Final output is a numeric distance; there are no Boolean range checks or letter grades.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for grade ranges C and D
misconceptions.description: The program does not implement any checks for whether a grade falls into the C (70-79) or D (60-69) ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears unaware that the problem requires mapping numeric grades in multiple ranges to letters C and D.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: After handling A and B, the program should check if the grade is between 70-79 for C or 60-69 for D using appropriate else-if conditions.
symptoms: No conditions involving thresholds 60 or 70
No branches that would result in outputting C or D
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Extend the if/else-if chain with `else if (grade >= 70) { ... } else if (grade >= 60) { ... }` to cover C and D ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no grade variable or any conditional logic to support such ranges.

evidence.note: All logic is numeric computation for distance; nothing resembles grade range checks.

misconceptions.name: Missing default/else case for failing grades
misconceptions.description: The code does not include any conditional structure, so there is no default or else branch to handle grades below 60 (F).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student is not considering classification of low grades at all, likely due to solving the wrong problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The grade calculator should ensure that any grade not matching A-D ranges falls into an F category, typically implemented as the final else branch.
symptoms: No else block
No reference to F or failing case
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete mismatch with the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After checking A-D ranges, use a final `else` to handle all remaining grades as F and print the corresponding letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absence of any conditional logic guarantees missing F handling.

evidence.note: The structure of main has no if/else blocks that could serve as default grade handling.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: No letter grade output mapping implemented
misconceptions.description: The program never outputs any letter grade (A, B, C, D, F); it only prints the numeric distance between two points.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the required output is the distance between two points, not a letter grade string.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should output `Letter grade: X` where X is one of A, B, C, D, F, depending on the numeric grade range.
symptoms: Output string mentions distance, not 'Letter grade'
No character or string variables holding letter grades
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusing this exercise with a different one (distance calculation).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the distance-related println with `System.out.println("Letter grade: " + letter);` after computing the appropriate letter.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categorical labels
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Output message is clearly about distance; there is zero reference to grades or letters.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distanceBetweenPoints);
evidence.note: Final output clearly does not match the expected 'Letter grade: B' style output.

misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for an entirely different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the Grade Calculator program required by Q3. The core logic (reading a single input, using if/else structures for grading) is completely absent.

Reads four double inputs, not a single grade input (0-100).
The core logic is calculating Euclidean distance, which is irrelevant to grade calculation.
